question: Question_02_(a)
sols:
For the one dimensional wave equation

\begin{align*}\begin{cases}
u_{tt} = c^2 u_{xx} \\
u(x,0) = f(x) \\
u_t(x,0) = g(x) 
\end{cases}\end{align*} where $-\infty < x < \infty$ and $t>0 \,$, the solution
$u(x,t)$ is given by d'Alembert's formula

\begin{align*}u(x,t) = \frac{1}{2} [f(x-ct) + f(x+ct)] + \frac{1}{2c} \int_{x-ct}^{x+ct} g(s) ds .\end{align*}

For this question, we have $c =1 \,$,

\begin{align*}f(x) = \begin{cases}
 2 \sin(2x) & 0 < x < \pi \\
 0 & \text{otherwise}
 \end{cases}\end{align*} and $g(x) = 0  \,$. Therefore, the solution is given by

\begin{align*}u(x,t) =  \frac{1}{2} [f(x-t) + f(x+t)] . \,\end{align*}

This equation says that at time $t = 0$, the original wave form splits
into two parts, each with half the amplitude of the original. One part
moves to the left at speed 1 and the other moves to the right at the
same speed. At any time $t>0$, the solution of the wave equation is the
sum of the left-traveling part and the right-traveling part.

At $t = 0$, $u(x,0)$ is the given function $f(x)$.
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH257_December_2011_Question_2_(a)_2sin2x.png}\\
To find $u \left( x,\frac{\pi}{4} \right)$, one imagines that at
$t = 0$, the original wave form $f(x)$ splits into two equal pieces but
with half the original amplitude. Hence, in this case, each part will be
like $\sin(2x)$. One part will move towards the left at speed 1 and the
other moves to the right at speed 1. At $t = \frac{\pi}{4}$, one part
has traveled $\frac{\pi}{4}$ units to the left and the other has
traveled $\frac{\pi}{4}$ units to the right. The solution
$u \left( x,\frac{\pi}{4} \right)$ is the sum of those two parts.

\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH257_December_2011_Question_2_(a)_sin2x.png}
Notice that in the above, the left traveling wave cancels with the right
travelling wave in the interval from $x = \frac{\pi}{4}$ to
$x = \frac{3\pi}{4}$.

Similarly, one finds the solutions for $u \left(x,\frac{\pi}{2} \right)$
and $u \left(x,\frac{3\pi}{4} \right)$.
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH257_December_2011_Question_2_(a)_sin2x_2.png}

\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH257_December_2011_Question_2_(a)_Sin2x_3.png}
